articles.headline: Food Experts Predict ‘Imminent’ Famine in Northern Gaza
articles.snippet: The warning came amid an Israeli raid on Al-Shifa Hospital. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu also agreed to send military and humanitarian officials to Washington to hear the Biden administration’s concerns.
articles.abstract: The warning came amid an Israeli raid on Al-Shifa Hospital. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu also agreed to send military and humanitarian officials to Washington to hear the Biden administration’s concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: The acute food shortage in the war-ravaged Gaza Strip has become so severe that “famine is imminent” and the enclave is on the verge of a “major acceleration of deaths and malnutrition,” a report from a global authority on food security and nutrition said on Monday.
articles.byline: By Gaya Gupta, Shashank Bengali and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: From Russia, Elaborate Tales of Fake Journalists
articles.snippet: As the Ukraine war grinds on, the Kremlin has created increasingly complex fabrications online to discredit Ukraine’s leader and undercut aid. Some have a Hollywood-style plot twist.
articles.abstract: As the Ukraine war grinds on, the Kremlin has created increasingly complex fabrications online to discredit Ukraine’s leader and undercut aid. Some have a Hollywood-style plot twist.
articles.lead_paragraph: A young man calling himself Mohamed al-Alawi appeared in a YouTube video in August. He described himself as an investigative journalist in Egypt with a big scoop: The mother-in-law of Ukraine’s president had purchased a villa near Angelina Jolie’s in El Gouna, a resort town on the Red Sea.

articles.headline: Japan Raises Interest Rates for First Time in 17 Years
articles.snippet: Higher inflation and rising wages suggest that the country’s economy can grow without such aggressive stimulus from the central bank.
articles.abstract: Higher inflation and rising wages suggest that the country’s economy can grow without such aggressive stimulus from the central bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: Japan’s central bank raised interest rates for the first time since 2007 on Tuesday, pushing them above zero to close a chapter in its aggressive effort to stimulate an economy that has long struggled to grow.
articles.byline: By Joe Rennison and Kiuko Notoya

articles.headline: How Anti-Immigrant Anger Has Divided a Small Irish Town
articles.snippet: A continuing protest in the town of Roscrea symbolizes a surge in hostility toward migrants in Ireland that is fueled by a housing crisis and far-right influencers.
articles.abstract: A continuing protest in the town of Roscrea symbolizes a surge in hostility toward migrants in Ireland that is fueled by a housing crisis and far-right influencers.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a cold January afternoon in Roscrea, a market town of around 5,500 people in rural Ireland, news began to spread that the town’s only remaining hotel would close temporarily — to provide housing for 160 asylum seekers.

articles.headline: Fed Meets Amid Worries That Inflation Progress Might Stall
articles.snippet: Inflation had been moderating steadily, but it is now hovering around 3 percent. Will lowering it fully to normal levels prove difficult?
articles.abstract: Inflation had been moderating steadily, but it is now hovering around 3 percent. Will lowering it fully to normal levels prove difficult?
articles.lead_paragraph: Slowing America’s rapid inflation has been an unexpectedly painless process so far. High interest rates are making it expensive to take out a mortgage or borrow to start a business, but they have not slammed the brakes on economic growth or drastically pushed up unemployment.

articles.headline: Goon Squad Officer Is Sentenced to 20 Years in Mississippi Torture Cases
articles.snippet: Six officers pleaded guilty last year to assaulting two Black men and shooting one of them in the mouth during a raid on their home.
articles.abstract: Six officers pleaded guilty last year to assaulting two Black men and shooting one of them in the mouth during a raid on their home.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two former law enforcement officers who were part of a self-styled “Goon Squad” that tortured, sexually assaulted and beat residents of a Mississippi county were given hefty prison sentences on Tuesday for brutally attacking two Black men last year.
articles.byline: By Nate Rosenfield, Jerry Mitchell and Brian Howey

articles.headline: Hong Kong Adopts Sweeping Security Laws, Bowing to Beijing
articles.snippet: The legislation targets “external interference” and the theft of state secrets, with implications for businesses, journalists, civil servants and others.
articles.abstract: The legislation targets “external interference” and the theft of state secrets, with implications for businesses, journalists, civil servants and others.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hong Kong on Tuesday passed national security laws at the behest of Beijing, thwarting decades of public resistance in a move that critics say will strike a lasting blow to the partial autonomy the city had been promised by China.
articles.byline: By Tiffany May and David Pierson

articles.headline: Israel Faces Tough Balancing Act on Russia and the West
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu treads lightly with President Vladimir Putin. Russia is not responding in kind, with public criticism increasing.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu treads lightly with President Vladimir Putin. Russia is not responding in kind, with public criticism increasing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israel, though heavily dependent on support from the United States, Germany and other Western nations, has been noticeably out of step with them when it comes to relations with Russia during its war of conquest in Ukraine.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Adam Sella

articles.headline: Japan’s Labor Market Has a Lesson for the Fed: Women Can Surprise You
articles.snippet: Japan’s improved labor force participation for women is a reminder not to assume that job market limits are clear and finite.
articles.abstract: Japan’s improved labor force participation for women is a reminder not to assume that job market limits are clear and finite.
articles.lead_paragraph: Japan’s economy has rocketed into the headlines this year as inflation returns for the first time in decades, workers win wage gains and the Bank of Japan raises interest rates for the first time in 17 years.
